From: Cisco IOS Configuration Fundamentals Command Reference
FuncDef: To display general information about the router when it reports a problem, use the **show tech-support**command in privileged EXEC mode.
CLIs: show tech-support [ page ] [ password ] [ cef | ipc | ipmulticast [ vrf <vrf-name> ] | isis | mpls | ospf [ <process-id> | detail ] | rsvp | voice | wccp ]
show tech-support [ cef | ipmulticast [ vrf <vrf-name> ] | isis | password [ page ] | platform | page | rsvp ]

ParaDef.Info: (Optional) Causes the output to display a page of information at a time.
(Optional) Leaves passwords and other security information in the output.
(Optional) Displays **show** command output specific to Cisco Express Forwarding.
(Optional) Specifies a multicast Virtual Private Network (VPN) routing and forwarding instance (VRF).

Examples: For a sample display of the output from the show tech-supportcommand, refer to the documentation for the show commands listed in the "Usage Guidelines" section.
ExtraInfo: To interrupt and terminate the **show tech-support** output, simultaneously press and release the **CTRL**, **ALT**, and **6** keys.Press the **Return** key to display the next line of output, or press the **Spacebar** to display the next page of information. If you do not enter the **page** keyword, the output scrolls (that is, it does not stop for page breaks).If you do not enter the **password** keyword, passwords and other security-sensitive information in the output are replaced with the label "<removed>."The show tech-support command is useful for collecting a large amount of information about your routing device for troubleshooting purposes. The output of this command can be provided to technical support representatives when reporting a problem.![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/note.gif)---**Note** ![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)This command can generate a very large amount of output. You may want to redirect the output to a file using the **show inventory | redirect** *url* command syntax extension. Redirecting the output to a file also makes sending this output to your technical support representative easier. See the command documentation for **show <command> | redirect** for more information on this option.---The show tech-support command displays the output of a number of **show** commands at once. The output from this command varies depending on your platform and configuration. For example, access servers display voice-related **show** command output. Additionally, the show protocol traffic commands are displayed for only the protocols enabled on your device. For a sample display of the output of the **show tech-support** command, see the individual **show** command listed.If you enter the **show tech-support** command without arguments, the output displays, but is not limited to, the equivalent of these **show** commands:•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show appletalk traffic** •![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show bootflash** •![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show bootvar** •![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show buffers** •![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show cdp neighbors** •![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show cef** •![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show clns traffic**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show context**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show controllers**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show decnet traffic**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show disk0: all** •![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)show dmvpn details•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show environment** •![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)show fabric channel-counters•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show file systems** •![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show interfaces**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show interfaces switchport**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show interfaces trunk**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show ip interface** •![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show ip traffic**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show logging** •![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show mac-address-table**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show module**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show power**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show processes cpu**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show processes memory**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show running-config**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show spanning-tree**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show stacks**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show version**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show vlan**![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/note.gif)---**Note** ![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)Crypto information is not duplicated by the **show dmvpn details** command output.---When the **show tech-support** command is entered on a virtual switch (VS), the output displays the output of the **show module** command and the **show power** command for both the active and standby switches.Use of the optional cef, ipc, ipmulticast, isis, mpls, ospf, or rsvp keywords provides a way to display a number of **show** commands specific to a particular protocol or process in addition to the show commands listed previously.For example, if your Technical Assistance Center (TAC) support representative suspects that you may have a problem in your Cisco Express Forwarding (CEF) configuration, you may be asked to provide the output of the show tech-support cef command. The show tech-support [page] [password] cef command will display the output from the following commands in addition to the output for the standard show tech-support command:•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show adjacency summary** •![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show cef drop**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show cef events**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show cef interface**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show cef not-cef-switched**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show cef timers**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show interfaces stats** •![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show ip cef events summary** •![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show ip cef inconsistency records detail**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show ip cef summary**If you enter the **ipmulticast** keyword, the output displays, but is not limited to, these **show** commands:•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show ip dvmrp route**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show ip igmp groups**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show ip igmp interface**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show ip mcache**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show ip mroute**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show ip mroute count**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show ip pim interface**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show ip pim interface count**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show ip pim interface df**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show ip pim mdt**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show ip pim mdt bgp**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show ip pim neighbor**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show ip pim rp**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show ip pim rp metric**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show mls ip multicast rp-mapping gm-cache**•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)show mmls gc process•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)show mmls msc rpdf-cacheIf you enter the **wccp** keyword, the output displays, but is not limited to, these **show** commands:•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show ip wccp** *service-number*•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**show ip wccp interfaces cef**

RelatedCmds.description: Displays a list of files on a file system.
Displays statistics about AppleTalk traffic, including MAC IP traffic.
Displays the contents of boot flash memory.

Displays the contents of the BOOT environment variable, the name of the configuration file pointed to by the CONFIG_FILE environment variable, the contents of the BOOTLDR environment variable, and the configuration register setting.
Displays statistics for the buffer pools on the network server.
Displays detailed information about neighboring devices discovered using Cisco Discovery Protocol.
Displays information about packets forwarded by Cisco Express Forwarding.
Displays a list of the CLNS packets this router has seen.
redirect
Displays context data.
Displays information that is specific to the hardware.
Displays general information about a VIP card for problem reporting.
Displays the DECnet traffic statistics (including datagrams sent, received, and forwarded).
Displays flash or file system information for a disk located in slot 0:
Displays detail DMVPN information for each session, including Next Hop Server (NHS) and NHS status, crypto session information, and socket details.

Displays temperature, voltage, and blower information on the Cisco 7000 series routers, Cisco 7200 series routers, Cisco 7500 series routers, Cisco 7600 series routers, Cisco AS5300 series access servers, and the Gigabit Switch Router.
Displays the fabric channel counters for a module.
Lists available file systems.
Displays statistics for all interfaces configured on the router or access server.
Displays the administrative and operational status of a switching (nonrouting) port.
Displays the interface-trunk information.
Displays the product inventory listing and UDI of all Cisco products installed in the networking device.
Displays the usability status of interfaces configured for IP.
Displays statistics about IP traffic.
Displays global statistics related to WCCP.
Displays the state of syslog and the contents of the standard system logging buffer.
Displays the MAC address table.
Displays module status and information.
Displays the current power status of system components.
Displays information about the active processes.
Displays the amount of memory used.
Displays the current configuration of your routing device.
Displays information about the spanning tree state.
Displays the stack usage of processes and interrupt routines.
Displays the configuration of the system hardware, the software version, the names and sources of configuration files, and the boot images.
Displays VLAN information.
